docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: With unprecedented rises in premiums (''Frustration Grows With the Cost of Health Insurance,'' front page, Sept. 18), coverage under health maintenance organizations has become a luxury for those who can afford it. A free market ideally fosters competition so that consumers benefit from better quality at reduced prices.
docs.abstract: Margaret W Leung letter on Sept 18 article calls for government action to make health insurance affordable

docs.lead_paragraph: Kevin Heebner, owner of a building supply store in Temple, Pa., got a call four years ago from his longtime stockbroker recommending an investment in short-term bonds. Assured the bonds were safe, Mr. Heebner invested $100,000. Three months later, Mr. Heebner received a stunning phone call. The broker told him the money he had put into the bonds was gone. The president of the broker's firm, Old Naples Securities, had stolen it.

headline.main: Many Holes Weaken Safety Net For Victims of Failed Brokerages

docs.abstract: Securities Investor Protection Corp provides safety net for investors that is full of holes; corporation, industry-financed but not government-backed, is chartered to protect each investor with securities held at member brokerage firm for up to $500,000, with claims for cash limited to $100,000 per customer; convincing it to pay can be extremely difficult, since it requires investors to run gantlet of legal technicalities that would challenge even those knowledgable about securities law; securities lawyers say situation arises because trustees overseeing cases are chosen by, and paid by, corporation, compared to independent trustees who are appointed by courts to handle corporate bankruptcy cases, and are working for people owed money; trustees working for Investor Protection Corp, many from coterie of lawyers who have made lucrative speciality of such cases, have received far more representing corporation than corporation has paid to investors; critics say trustees wanting repeat business from corporation have incentive to minimize payouts to investors; system's shortcomings are evidence in case of Kevin Heebner, who battled corporation to recover part of $100,000 investment; photos; charts (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Vice President Al Gore opened a week dedicated to highlighting his differences with Gov. George W. Bush over Medicare by asserting today that Mr. Bush's plan for providing prescription drug benefits would force some low-income elderly people to go to welfare offices to qualify. Mr. Bush's aides called that contention ''pure fantasy'' and ''a classic scare tactic.'' The Bush campaign, meanwhile, vowed to wage a war against America's ''education recession'' in the week before the 2000 campaign becomes consumed by the long-awaited first debate between the Democratic and Republican presidential contenders. Aides at Mr. Bush's headquarters in Austin, Tex., buoyed by a polling rebound that accompanied the Texas governor's first good week in a month, also disparaged Mr. Gore for what they portrayed as his recent misstatements.

headline.main: Differences on Medicare Take Center Stage in Gore Campaign

docs.abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore begins week dedicated to highlighting his differences with Gov George W Bush over Medicare by asserting that Bush's plan for providing prescription drug benefits would force some low-income elderly people to go to welfare offices to qualify; Bush's aides dismiss contention as 'pure fantasy' and 'classic scare tactic' (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: They are bad. Really bad. Malevolent even. And not just bad. They are big. Big and bad, like those nightmarish, saw-toothed meanies that lurk beneath the bed. They are Vice President Al Gore's bogeymen -- big oil, big drug companies, big health insurers, big polluters. For good measure, Mr. Gore still throws in big tobacco from time to time. They are out there, threatening America's prosperity. And like politicians before him, Mr. Gore hopes to ride the public's trepidation about them all the way to the White House.

headline.main: Gore Takes an Approach Both Risky and Calculated

docs.abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore hopes to ride public's trepidation about big oil, big drug companies, big health insurers and big polluters all the way to White House; it has been decades since politician denounced such broad array of corporate targets with such pointed language; for Gore, it is part of broader positioning of his campaign as ' for the people,' while portraying Gov George W Bush and Republicans as 'for the powerful'; Gore's tactic is not without risk of being branded hypocrite (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Frustration Grows With Cost of Health Insurance'' (front page, Sept. 18): You note that both political parties have proposals intended to control health care costs. But you do not acknowledge that both presidential candidates and members of both parties support ''patients' rights'' legislation that would significantly raise the cost of health insurance, raising the number of uninsured Americans.
docs.abstract: Health Insurance Association of America Pres Charles N Kahn III letter responds to Sept 18 article; notes that Vice Pres Al Gore and Gov George W Bush support 'patients rights' legislation that would raise health insurance costs

docs.lead_paragraph: THE shortage of school bus drivers resulting from the expanding economy and the state's low unemployment rate has made the first few weeks of the school year chaotic ones. Buses in many towns are regularly late, routes have been expanded so students have to leave for school earlier and get home later, and in some cases, most notably in Stamford where the shortage has been acute, buses haven't come at all. The problem has gotten so bad, and the search for new drivers so futile, that some bus companies have offered up to $2,000 signing bonuses for drivers, increased wages by more than 30 percent, and have put their office staff on the road. In at least two cases, company presidents have had to get behind the wheel to keep the buses running.

headline.main: Bus Driver Shortage Leaving Students At the Curb

docs.abstract: Late school buses or no shows become more common in Connecticut, most notably in Stamford, as result of acute shortage of drivers; officials blame robust economy and state's low unemployment rate; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Healthpass, an insurance program for small businesses that lets workers choose from 20 different health plans, will expand from New York City to Westchester on Oct. 1. The program, which was initiated in November with a $1 million grant from the city government, lets companies with less than 50 workers set their contribution level while allowing employees to choose from plans offered by four insurance companies.

headline.main: Health Insurance Program Comes to the County

docs.abstract: Healthpass, insurance program for small businesses that allows workers to choose from 20 different health plans, will expand from New York City to Westchester County on October 1 (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Forty states will soon lose hundreds of millions of dollars of federal money that was supposed to provide health insurance to children in low-income families, federal and state officials say. The money -- 45 percent of the $4.2 billion provided by Congress -- remains unspent by the states after three years. It will be given to New York and nine other states that used their full allotments of federal money under the Children's Health Insurance Program, which was created by Congress, with much enthusiasm and fanfare, in 1997.

headline.main: 40 STATES FORFEIT HEALTH CARE FUNDS FOR POOR CHILDREN

docs.abstract: Federal and state officials say 40 states will lose hundreds of millions of dollars set aside to provide health insurance to children in low-income families; money, totaling 45 percent of $4.2 billion provided by Congress, remains unspent by states after three years; will be given to New York and nine other states that used full allotments of federal money under Children's Health Insurance Program, created by Congress in 1997 amid enthusiasm and fanfare; California and Texas, which together have 29 percent of nation's 11 million uninsured children, account for more than half of unspent money (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL 3-23 Industrial Powers Push For Cut in Oil Prices Top American financial officials, fresh from parallel plunges into world oil and currency markets, joined Group of 7 allies in promising to fight what they labeled twin threats to the record-breaking American economic expansion. The allies negotiated a joint communique calling on oil-producing nations to cut prices, saying a reduction was ''crucial for the world economy.'' 1

docs.lead_paragraph: The national debate over health policy, which first occupied the top rungs of the political agenda in the 1992 presidential campaign, shifts focus as the nature of problems shifts. In the mid 1990's, the focus was on the soaring cost of health insurance. Toward the end of the 90's, attention shifted to alleged excesses of managed care plans. But one problem never fades away. That is the shameful fact that the United States is the only industrialized power that does not provide some form of universal health coverage for its people. Some 45 million Americans still lack health insurance, and despite a decade of prosperity, the number is growing. The issue is not just that the uninsured live in constant fear of financial catastrophe. They also suffer medically from the lack of ongoing basic treatment. Studies show that the uninsured are substantially more likely to require hospitalization for festering medical problems like diabetes.
docs.abstract: Editorial holds that it is shameful fact that US is only industrialized power that does not provide some form of universal health coverage for its people; criticizes Vice Pres Al Gore and Gov George W Bush for not proposing such plan during presidential campaign
